item.title: Love Blooms: Romance Book Recommendations To Read This Summer
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

Looking for your next great romance read to sit out on a picnic blanket and indulge in this spring and summer? Whether you're lounging in the park, sipping on iced coffee at your favorite café, or simply curling up at home, there's nothing quite like getting lost in a captivating love story. From enchanting historical romances to sizzling contemporary tales, the world of romance literature offers something for every reader's taste. In this blog post, I'll be sharing a curated list of romance book recommendations that are perfect for this spring and summer. So grab your favorite blanket, brew a cup of tea, and prepare to fall head over heels in love with these delightful reads! A friend recommended The Summer of Broken Rules and I am already halfway through it, it's so good!

"The Lost Apothecary" by Sarah Penner

A blend of historical fiction and contemporary storytelling, this novel intertwines the stories of a hidden apothecary in 18th-century London and a present-day woman in search of answers about her past.

"People We Meet on Vacation" by Emily Henry

A delightful rom-com about two polar opposite best friends who take annual vacations together, exploring their complicated relationship over the years.

"The Dating Playbook" by Farrah Rochon

This charming romance follows a former NFL player turned relationship coach who finds himself falling for the woman he's supposed to be helping find love.

"The Soulmate Equation" by Christina Lauren

In a near-future setting, this novel explores the idea of a scientific approach to finding love through a DNA matchmaking service, with unexpected results.

The Summer of Broken Rules by K.L. Walther

"The Summer of Broken Rules" by K.L. Walther is a captivating summer romance that follows Meredith, who reluctantly agrees to spend the summer at her family's beach house after a difficult breakup. Determined to avoid any romantic entanglements, Meredith devises a set of rules to protect her heart. However, her plans are thrown into disarray when she meets the charming and mysterious Eli. As Meredith navigates her growing feelings for Eli and confronts her past, she learns the power of forgiveness, the importance of taking risks, and the beauty of second chances. Set against the backdrop of a picturesque seaside town, "The Summer of Broken Rules" is a poignant and uplifting story about love, healing, and the joys of embracing life's unexpected twists and turns.

"Second First Impressions" by Sally Thorne

From the author of "The Hating Game" comes a quirky and heartwarming romance set in a retirement community, where an uptight manager finds herself drawn to a tattooed, motorcycle-riding tenant.

Act Your Age, Eve Brown" by Talia Hibbert

The final installment in the "Brown Sisters" trilogy, this book follows the free-spirited Eve Brown as she clashes with a grumpy B&B owner who needs her help but doesn't want to admit it.

item.title: Books To Read If You Loved Fourth Wing
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
If you enjoyed "Fourth Wing," a fantasy novel with elements of adventure and intrigue, you might appreciate these fantasy books. So prepare to lose yourself in epic quests, enchanted forests, romance, and battles against the forces of darkness, as we unveil the fantastical worlds waiting to be discovered between the pages of these captivating tales!

What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

Crescent City Series

The Crescent City series by Sarah J. Maas is a captivating urban fantasy series set in the sprawling metropolis of Crescent City, where magic and technology intertwine in a world filled with intrigue, danger, and romance. This three book series is filled with action, magic, and romance, the Crescent City series is a gripping tale of friendship, betrayal, and redemption set against the backdrop of a vividly imagined world.

A Court of Thorn And Roses Series

The "A Court of Thorns and Roses" (ACOTAR) series by Sarah J. Maas is a spellbinding fantasy saga that follows the journey of Feyre Archeron, a young huntress, as she navigates a world filled with faeries, magic, and political intrigue. Filled with romance, adventure, and breathtaking world-building, the ACOTAR series is a captivating tale of love, sacrifice, and the enduring power of hope in the face of darkness.

The Cruel Prince by Holly Black


"The Cruel Prince" by Holly Black is a captivating fantasy novel set in the world of Faerie, where intrigue, betrayal, and magic reign supreme. Filled with twists and turns, "The Cruel Prince" is a gripping tale of power, ambition, and the price of belonging in a world where nothing is as it seems. Holly Black's lush prose and vivid world-building bring the enchanting realm of Faerie to life, making this book a must-read for fans of dark fantasy and intricate storytelling.

"The Way of Kings" by Brandon Sanderson

"The Way of Kings" is the first book in Brandon Sanderson's epic fantasy series, "The Stormlight Archive." Set in the vast and richly imagined world of Roshar, the novel follows multiple characters whose lives are intertwined by fate and the looming threat of war.

With its stunning prose and epic scope, "The Way of Kings" is a must-read for fans of high fantasy and immersive storytelling. Brandon Sanderson's masterful blend of action, intrigue, and character development makes this book the beginning of an unforgettable series that will keep readers eagerly turning the pages until the very end.

Iron Flame (#2 in the series)

    Iron Flame is the second book in the Empyrean Series so if you enjoyed Fourth Wing, you will DEFINETLY enjoy this! The second book continues with the beloved characters from Fourth Wing. "Iron Flame" is a gripping tale of courage, resilience, and the unbreakable bonds that unite us in the face of adversity. Rebecca Yarros's evocative prose and compelling storytelling will keep readers on the edge of their seats until the very end, making this novel a must-read for fans of romantic suspense.

item.title: Delicious and Easy Dutch Oven Mojo Pork
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
Making mojo pork in a Dutch oven is a great idea! Mojo pork, a traditional Cuban dish, is marinated in a citrusy, garlicky sauce and slow-cooked until tender. Here's a simple recipe for making mojo pork in a Dutch oven. A dutch oven is a great way to make simple and delicious meals.

What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

I use this 5 quart dutch oven all the time from Lodge (click the image to shop now)

Dutch Oven Mojo Pork

Making mojo pork in a Dutch oven is a great idea! Mojo pork, a traditional Cuban dish, is marinated in a citrusy, garlicky sauce and slow-cooked until tender. Here's a simple recipe for making mojo pork in a Dutch oven:

  • - 3-4 pounds pork shoulder (also known as pork butt, trimmed of excess fat and cut into large chunks)
  • - 1 cup orange juice
  • - 1/2 cup lime juice
  • - Zest of 1 orange and 1 lime
  • - 8 cloves garlic (minced)
  • - 1 teaspoon ground cumin
  • - 1 teaspoon dried oregano
  • - 1 teaspoon salt
  • - 1/2 teaspoon black pepper
  • - 1/4 cup olive oil
  • - 1 onion (thinly sliced)
  • - 1 jalapeño pepper (seeded and minced (optional, for heat))
  • - Fresh cilantro (chopped (for garnish))
  • - Lime wedges (for serving)

  1. Marinate: In a large bowl, combine orange juice, lime juice, orange zest, lime zest, minced garlic, ground cumin, dried oregano, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Mix well. Place the pork chunks in the marinade, ensuring they are well coated. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.

  2. Preheat the Dutch Oven: Preheat your oven to 325°F (160°C). Remove the marinated pork from the refrigerator and let it come to room temperature while you prepare the Dutch oven.

  3. Sear the Pork: Heat the Dutch oven over medium-high heat on the stovetop. Add a little oil if needed. Once the Dutch oven is hot, sear the marinated pork pieces in batches until they are browned on all sides. This step helps to develop flavor.

  4. Cook the Pork: Once all the pork pieces are seared, return them all to the Dutch oven. Add sliced onions and minced jalapeño pepper (if using) to the Dutch oven, distributing them evenly around the pork. Cover the Dutch oven with its lid and transfer it to the preheated oven. Cook the pork for about 3 to 4 hours, or until the meat is very tender and easily shreds with a fork.

  5. Serve! Once the pork is done, remove it from the oven. Use two forks to shred the pork into bite-sized pieces. Serve the mojo pork hot, garnished with chopped cilantro and lime wedges on the side.

Ingredients:

  • 3-4 pounds pork shoulder (also known as pork butt), trimmed of excess fat and cut into large chunks
  • 1 cup orange juice
  • 1/2 cup lime juice
  • Zest of 1 orange and 1 lime
  • 8 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 teaspoon ground cumin
  • 1 teaspoon dried oregano
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 1/2 teaspoon black pepper
  • 1/4 cup olive oil
  • 1 onion, thinly sliced
  • 1 jalapeño pepper, seeded and minced (optional, for heat)
  • Fresh cilantro, chopped (for garnish)
  • Lime wedges (for serving)

Instructions:

Marinate the Pork:

    • In a large bowl, combine orange juice, lime juice, orange zest, lime zest, minced garlic, ground cumin, dried oregano, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Mix well.
    • Place the pork chunks in the marinade, ensuring they are well coated. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.

    Preheat the Dutch Oven:

      • Preheat your oven to 325°F (160°C).
      • Remove the marinated pork from the refrigerator and let it come to room temperature while you prepare the Dutch oven.

      Sear the Pork:

        • Heat the Dutch oven over medium-high heat on the stovetop. Add a little oil if needed.
        • Once the Dutch oven is hot, sear the marinated pork pieces in batches until they are browned on all sides. This step helps to develop flavor.

        Cook the Pork:

          • Once all the pork pieces are seared, return them all to the Dutch oven.
          • Add sliced onion and minced jalapeño pepper (if using) to the Dutch oven, distributing them evenly around the pork.
          • Cover the Dutch oven with its lid and transfer it to the preheated oven.
          • Cook the pork for about 3 to 4 hours, or until the meat is very tender and easily shreds with a fork.

          Serve:

            • Once the pork is done, remove it from the oven.
            • Use two forks to shred the pork into bite-sized pieces.
            • Serve the mojo pork hot, garnished with chopped cilantro and lime wedges on the side.

            Enjoy your delicious mojo pork made in a Dutch oven! It pairs wonderfully with rice, beans, or warm tortillas.

item.title: Your New Go To Dinner: Greek Chicken Bowls
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
Greek chicken bowls are delicious and packed with Mediterranean flavors. Ever since watching the "Blue Zones" documentary on Netflix, my husband and I have tried to incorporate more recipes from Blue Zones around the world into our weekly meals. We use recipes from this recipe book:

Blue Zones Kitchen

We have taken what we have learned from the blue zones recipe book and applied it to a go to meal in our home, Greek chicken bowls! We typically use Greek chicken thighs but you could sub the chicken thighs for chicken breasts or even use shrimp! Here's a simple recipe to make Greek chicken bowls:

What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

Ingredients:

For the Greek Chicken:

  • 1 lb (450g) chicken thighs
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • 3 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 teaspoon dried oregano
  • 1 teaspoon dried thyme
  • 1 teaspoon paprika
  • Salt and pepper to taste

For the Tzatziki Sauce:

  • 1 cup Greek yogurt
  • 1 cucumber, grated and excess water squeezed out
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 tablespoon fresh dill, chopped (or 1 teaspoon dried dill)
  • 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  • Salt and pepper to taste

For the Greek Bowl Toppings:

  • 1 cucumber, diced
  • 1 tomato, diced
  • 1/2 red onion, thinly sliced
  • 1/4 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and halved
  • 1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese
  • Fresh parsley, chopped

For Serving:

  • Cooked quinoa or rice
  • Pita bread or flatbread (optional)

Instructions:

1. Marinate and Cook the Chicken:

  1. In a bowl, combine the olive oil, minced garlic, dried oregano, dried thyme, paprika, salt, and pepper.
  2. Add the chicken to the marinade and toss until well coated. Let it marinate for at least 15 minutes.
  3. Preheat your oven to 400 degrees. Arrange the chicken on a sheet pan and cook for 20-25 minutes (or until interior temperature reaches 165 degrees).

2. Prepare the Tzatziki Sauce:

  1. In a bowl, combine the Greek yogurt, grated cucumber, minced garlic, dill, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Mix well until smooth and creamy. Adjust seasoning to taste. Refrigerate until ready to use.

3. Assemble the Greek Salad:

  1. In another bowl, combine the diced cucumber, tomato, sliced red onion, Kalamata olives, crumbled feta cheese, and chopped parsley. Toss gently to combine.

4. Assemble the Greek Chicken Bowls:

  1. To assemble, divide cooked quinoa or rice among serving bowls.
  2. Top each bowl with the Greek chicken, Greek salad, and a generous dollop of tzatziki sauce.
  3. Serve immediately, optionally with pita bread or flatbread on the side.

Enjoy your flavorful Greek chicken bowl! Adjust ingredients and quantities according to your taste preferences.

Greek chicken bowls are delicious and packed with Mediterranean flavors. Here's a simple recipe to make Greek chicken bowls:

  • Ingredients:
  • For the Greek Chicken:
  • - 1 lb (450g chicken breast, cut into bite-sized pieces)
  • - 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • - 3 cloves garlic (minced)
  • - 1 teaspoon dried oregano
  • - 1 teaspoon dried thyme
  • - 1 teaspoon paprika
  • - Salt and pepper to taste
  • For the Tzatziki Sauce:
  • - 1 cup Greek yogurt
  • - 1 cucumber (grated and excess water squeezed out)
  • - 2 cloves garlic (minced)
  • - 1 tablespoon fresh dill (chopped (or 1 teaspoon dried dill))
  • - 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  • - Salt and pepper to taste
  • For the Greek Salad:
  • - 1 cucumber (diced)
  • - 1 tomato (diced)
  • - 1/2 red onion (thinly sliced)
  • - 1/4 cup Kalamata olives (pitted and halved)
  • - 1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese
  • - Fresh parsley (chopped)
  • For Serving:
  • - Cooked quinoa or rice
  • - Pita bread or flatbread (optional)
  1. Instructions:

  2. Marinate and Cook the Chicken:

  3. In a bowl, combine the olive oil, minced garlic, dried oregano, dried thyme, paprika, salt, and pepper.
  4. Add the chicken pieces to the marinade and toss until well coated. Let it marinate for at least 15 minutes.
  5. Heat a large skillet or grill pan over medium-high heat. Add the marinated chicken pieces and cook until golden brown and cooked through, about 5-7 minutes, flipping halfway through. Remove from heat and set aside.

  6. Prepare the Tzatziki Sauce:

  7. In a bowl, combine the Greek yogurt, grated cucumber, minced garlic, dill, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Mix well until smooth and creamy. Adjust seasoning to taste. Refrigerate until ready to use.

  8. Assemble the Greek Salad:

  9. In another bowl, combine the diced cucumber, tomato, sliced red onion, Kalamata olives, crumbled feta cheese, and chopped parsley. Toss gently to combine.

  10. Assemble the Greek Chicken Bowls:

  11. To assemble, divide cooked quinoa or rice among serving bowls.
  12. Top each bowl with the Greek chicken, Greek salad, and a generous dollop of tzatziki sauce.
  13. Serve immediately, optionally with pita bread or flatbread on the side.

Enjoy your flavorful Greek chicken bowl! Adjust ingredients and quantities according to your taste preferences.

item.title: A Long Weekend in New Hampshire's White Mountains
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
Visiting the White Mountains National Forest offers a plethora of outdoor activities and scenic spots to explore. There are also amazing places to grab a bite to eat and New England's BEST Ice Cream. One of the reasons we moved to New England is the opportunity to take long weekend trips to so many places with different outdoor activities.

The White Mountains are a perfect location for a family friendly trip with loads of activities for all ages. From kayaking, hiking, swimming, to visiting museums there are a lot of activities to make memories as a family!

The White Mountains have so many beautiful hikes to choose from that range from beginner to expert, don't forget to pack a great hiking backpack with the necessary supplies for your trip! I have been using this one for years and it has held up really well:

The White Mountains are also a great spot for a romantic or solo weekend getaway. Grab a cabin for the weekend and explore the beautiful forest! Here’s a weekend itinerary to make the most of your trip:

What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

Day 1: Arrival and Exploration

Morning:

  • Arrival: Arrive at your accommodation in the White Mountains area.
  • Breakfast: Enjoy a hearty breakfast at a local diner or café. Polly's Pancake Parlor is a White Mountains STAPLE! Nothing like a stack of pancakes topped with real maple syrup to fuel your day of adventures!

Late Morning to Afternoon:

  • Visitor Center: Start at the White Mountains Visitor Center (located in Lincoln, NH) to get maps, trail information, and learn about current conditions.
  • Scenic Drive: Take the Kancamagus Highway (Route 112) for stunning views of the forest, stopping at overlooks like Kancamagus Pass and Sabbaday Falls for short hikes.

Evening:

  • Dinner: Have dinner at Woodstock Inn Brewery or pack a picnic to enjoy at a scenic spot.
  • Relaxation: Depending on your accommodation, relax and enjoy the surroundings.

Day 2: Outdoor Adventures

Morning:

  • Hiking: Choose a hike based on your skill level and interests. Popular options include:
    • Mount Washington: Summit hike or take the cog railway (advance reservations recommended).
    • Franconia Ridge Loop: Challenging but rewarding hike with stunning views.
    • Arethusa Falls: Easier hike leading to a beautiful waterfall.
    • Artists Bluff: This is a popular hiking trail for its easy access and rewarding views! Try going early in the morning to beat the crowds!

Afternoon:

  • Picnic Lunch: Pack a lunch or find a spot to picnic along your hike or at a scenic overlook.
  • Exploration: Visit attractions like Lost River Gorge and Boulder Caves or Flume Gorge for more natural beauty.
  • For the Outdoor Adventurer: Try your hand at Disc Golf or Mountain Biking at Loon Mountain Resort! If you are feeling really adventurous, you could do both in one day!

Evening:

  • Dinner: Enjoy a meal at Rek-Lis Brewery, they offer delcious food and a beautiful patio area for you to enjoy an al fresco dinner!
  • Dessert: We have tried A LOT of ice cream in the New England area and Super Secret Ice Cream is the BEST. There is a reason they have won awards for their ice cream. It is locally sourced and made in house. Try the honeycomb ice cream, you will not be disappointed!
  • Stargazing: If the weather permits, look for a spot away from city lights to enjoy the stars.

Day 3: Cultural and Relaxation

Morning:

  • Cultural Visit: Visit local museums or historical sites like the Castle in the Clouds or Mount Washington Observatory Weather Discovery Center.

Afternoon:

  • Relaxation: Consider activities like fishing, kayaking, swimming in a lake, or taking a scenic train ride on the Conway Scenic Railroad.

Departure:

  • Lunch: Enjoy a final meal in the area before heading home.

This itinerary provides a balanced mix of outdoor activities, sightseeing, and relaxation to make the most of your weekend in the White Mountains National Forest. Adjust activities based on your preferences and the season of your visit.

item.title: Book Recommendations On The History of Fiber Arts and Politics
item.dc:creator: whatmorgandoes
item.content:encoded:
What Morgan Does is reader-supported, if you purchase something after clicking on links in this post, I may earn some coffee money which I promise to drink while continuing to write! It does not affect the price of what you purchase.

In a world where social divides often seem insurmountable, fiber arts provide more than just a creative outlet—they are a way to stitch together the fabric of our shared human experience. From knitting needles to looms, from the vibrant hues of yarn to the intricate patterns of woven cloth, fiber arts are not merely about creating beautiful objects; they are about shaping culture, history, and politics. Several groundbreaking books explore the profound relationship between fiber arts and social change, revealing how knitting, sewing, and weaving have intersected with political movements, economics, and global histories.

Here’s a look at six books that delve into the social and political dimensions of fiber arts, shedding light on how these age-old practices continue to influence our world today.

1. No Idle Hands: The Social History of American Knitting by Anne Macdonald

Anne Macdonald's No Idle Hands offers a fascinating exploration of American knitting, tracing its evolution from a humble craft to a politically charged activity. Through a historical lens, Macdonald reveals how knitting, particularly among women, has always carried deeper meanings than mere decorative or utilitarian purposes. Whether knitting for economic necessity during wartime or using knitting as a form of rebellion and protest, Macdonald illustrates how the act of knitting has long been intertwined with social movements and political shifts. This book helps us understand knitting not just as a pastime, but as a powerful tool for expressing social change.

2. The Power of Knitting: Stitching Together Our Lives in a Fractured World by Loretta Napoleoni

Loretta Napoleoni’s The Power of Knitting moves beyond the domestic space and examines how knitting can act as a form of resistance in a fractured world. In a globalized society marked by political unrest, economic instability, and cultural dislocation, Napoleoni demonstrates how knitting has become a means of reclaiming agency and connection. The book discusses knitting as a tool for social cohesion, from creating solidarity across national boundaries to providing marginalized groups with a way to assert their identities. Napoleoni makes the case that knitting, often perceived as a solitary or meditative activity, can also serve as a collective force that unites people in a shared cause.

3. The New Politics of the Handmade by Anthea Black and Nicole Burisch

In The New Politics of the Handmade, Anthea Black and Nicole Burisch explore the intersections of craft, politics, and activism in the contemporary world. This book takes a critical look at the "handmade" movement, discussing how people today are reinterpreting traditional craft techniques in ways that challenge consumerism, mass production, and exploitative labor practices. The authors highlight how modern makers are using fiber arts—knitting, quilting, embroidery, and more—to raise awareness about social issues like environmental sustainability, labor rights, and the ethics of consumption. It’s a powerful reminder that, in the age of fast fashion and mass industrialization, the simple act of making by hand can be a potent form of political engagement.

4. The Fabric of Civilization: How Textiles Made the World by Virginia Postrel

Virginia Postrel's The Fabric of Civilization takes a sweeping historical view, exploring how textiles have shaped the course of human history. From the earliest discoveries of spinning and weaving to the role of fabrics in the global trade networks, Postrel traces how textiles have influenced everything from empire-building to the modern economy. She examines the political implications of textile production, such as the role of cotton in the American Civil War and the economic and environmental impacts of the textile industry today. For anyone interested in the far-reaching political and historical significance of fabric, this book offers a thought-provoking perspective on how textiles have woven themselves into the very fabric of civilization.

5. The Golden Thread: How Fabric Changed History by Kassia St. Clair

Kassia St. Clair's The Golden Thread is an evocative journey through the history of textiles, showing how fabric has not only reflected but also shaped the world’s political landscape. St. Clair traces the influence of fabric from ancient times to modern day, exploring how the textile trade has played a pivotal role in everything from wars and revolutions to fashion and the economy. The book demonstrates how textiles have served as symbols of power, prestige, and rebellion, and how the production and trade of fabric have often been at the heart of geopolitics. With a mix of historical narrative and engaging storytelling, St. Clair brings to light the importance of fabric in global history, providing readers with a new understanding of how something so simple has had such profound political ramifications.

6. Fray: Art and Textile Politics by Julia Bryan-Wilson

In Fray: Art and Textile Politics, Julia Bryan-Wilson examines the intersection of contemporary art and political activism through the lens of textiles. Focusing on how artists use fabric and textile-based art to address issues of race, gender, and social justice, Bryan-Wilson explores the revolutionary potential of textiles as a medium for political commentary. The book features a wide range of artists and activists who use textiles not only to create beautiful objects but also to challenge power structures, provoke thought, and inspire social change. It’s a deep dive into how fiber arts, often considered craft or decoration, can become a force for art activism.

The Political Power of Fiber Arts

Taken together, these books underscore the deep and often overlooked connections between fiber arts and politics. They remind us that the act of crafting is not simply a private or domestic pursuit, but an ongoing thread that runs through history, society, and politics. Whether knitting to support war efforts, weaving to challenge colonial exploitation, or creating art that sparks social change, fiber arts have always been a means of expression, resistance, and solidarity.

As these authors demonstrate, the threads that connect us through fiber arts are also the threads that bind us to a shared history and future—a future where crafting, activism, and politics can come together to weave a more inclusive, connected, and socially aware world. Whether you're an experienced maker or someone just learning the ropes, these books offer a powerful reminder of the lasting impact that fiber arts can have in shaping the world we live in.
